text: Who can utter the mighty acts of the LORD? who can shew forth all his praise?
text_kjv: Who can utter the mighty acts of the LORD? who can shew forth all his praise?
text_niv: Who can proclaim the mighty acts of the Lordor fully declare his praise?
text_esv: Who can utter the mighty deeds of the LORD, or declare all his praise?
text_nlt: Who can list the glorious miracles of the LORD?Who can ever praise him enough?
text_msg: But who on earth can do it—declaim God's mighty acts, broadcast all his praises?
text_nasb: Who can speak of the mighty deeds of the LORD, Or can show forth all His praise?
context: Psalm 106 is a historical psalm, recounting the Israelites' repeated rebellions and God's unwavering faithfulness throughout their history, from the Exodus to their experiences in the wilderness and eventual settlement (or lack thereof). The psalm is written in the aftermath of exile, likely after the return from Babylonian captivity. The author, presumably a Levite, seeks to remind the people of their past sins and God's enduring mercy, hoping to inspire repentance and renewed covenant faithfulness. The concept of 'uttering mighty acts' and 'shewing forth praise' reflects a cultural understanding of oral tradition and communal worship. In ancient Israel, history and theology were intertwined, passed down through stories and songs, connecting generations to their heritage and to God. The rhetorical question in verse 2 highlights the sheer magnitude of God's actions, emphasizing that human language and ability can never fully capture the extent of His power and grace. It implicitly calls for ongoing effort and dedication to remember and celebrate God’s deeds. This verse stands at the beginning of a long recounting of Israel's failures, it almost serves as a warning, that despite the inadequacy to fully express God's greatness, the attempt must be made, not just through praise but also through remembering and learning from the past. The very act of writing and reciting the psalm is an attempt to answer its own rhetorical question.
meaning: Psalm 106:2 grapples with the inherent limitations of human language and understanding when confronted with the infinite greatness of God. The rhetorical question emphasizes the disparity between God's boundless power and our finite capacity to articulate it. 'Mighty acts' refers not just to physical demonstrations of strength, like the plagues in Egypt or the parting of the Red Sea, but also to acts of covenant faithfulness, mercy, and enduring love. These actions reveal God's character and His commitment to His promises, even in the face of Israel's persistent disobedience. 'Shewing forth all his praise' speaks to the multifaceted nature of worship. It's not merely about singing hymns or offering sacrifices, but also about living a life that reflects God's glory, embodying His values, and proclaiming His goodness to others. The phrase 'all his praise' suggests that there is no limit to the ways in which God deserves to be honored. The verse highlights the importance of both individual and corporate worship. While no single person can fully comprehend or express God's greatness, the collective effort of believers, through their varied gifts and experiences, can offer a more complete, though still imperfect, representation of His praise. The theological implication is that God's glory infinitely surpasses human comprehension, yet He invites us to participate in revealing His glory, even imperfectly. The very attempt to praise and proclaim becomes an act of faith, acknowledging both God's transcendence and His immanence.
application: Psalm 106:2 challenges us today to consider how we are actively participating in 'uttering the mighty acts of the LORD' and 'shewing forth all his praise' in our daily lives. Are we content with passively observing God's work, or are we actively seeking ways to share His goodness with others? This can take many forms: sharing testimonies of God's faithfulness in our own lives, using our creative gifts to express our love for Him (through music, art, writing), volunteering in our communities to serve those in need, and advocating for justice and righteousness. We should reflect on the opportunities we miss to speak about God's influence. It also calls us to cultivate a spirit of gratitude and awe in our hearts, constantly reflecting on the blessings He has bestowed upon us. In a world saturated with noise and distractions, it is essential to carve out time for quiet reflection and prayer, allowing us to recognize God's hand at work in our lives. Further, this verse suggests we ought to be students of scripture and church history. The better we know God's past actions, the better we can appreciate His present work and anticipate His future plans. This verse also encourages us to remember and learn from the mistakes of the past, both individually and collectively as a church. We must not repeat the patterns of disobedience and idolatry that plagued ancient Israel, but instead strive to live lives of integrity and faithfulness. Critically, we must humbly acknowledge that our understanding of God is limited and incomplete. But that shouldn't hinder us from striving to be His faithful witnesses in the world. Recognizing our limitations allows us to rely more fully on the Holy Spirit to guide us in our efforts to proclaim His truth.
prayer: Lord, forgive us for the times we have been silent when we should have spoken of your mighty acts. Forgive us for taking your blessings for granted and for failing to share your love with others. Open our eyes to see your hand at work in our lives and in the world around us. Grant us the courage to proclaim your goodness, even when it is difficult or unpopular. Fill our hearts with gratitude and awe, that we may never cease to offer you our heartfelt praise. Help us to learn from the mistakes of the past and to live lives of integrity and faithfulness, reflecting your glory in all that we do. Empower us by your Holy Spirit to share your love. In Jesus' name we pray, Amen.

faqs.answer: This verse is directly related to evangelism as it calls believers to 'utter the mighty acts of the LORD,' which includes sharing the gospel – the story of Jesus' life, death, and resurrection – and 'shewing forth all his praise' by testifying to the transformative power of God in our lives. Evangelism is essentially the practical application of this verse.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: How does this verse relate to evangelism?

faqs.answer: 'Shewing forth all his praise' means expressing adoration and reverence for God in every aspect of life. This includes living ethically, serving others, pursuing justice, creating beauty, and using our gifts and talents to glorify Him. It's holistic worship extending beyond traditional acts of singing and praying.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean to 'shew forth all his praise' beyond just singing?

faqs.answer: Although we cannot fully capture God's glory, the act of trying is an act of obedience, faith, and love. Our imperfect attempts are pleasing to God and can inspire others to seek Him. It also deepens our own understanding and appreciation of His greatness, fostering a deeper relationship.
faqs.question: Q3: If we can't fully express God's glory, why bother trying?

faqs.answer: Even if you feel inadequate, you can still fulfill this verse by focusing on simple acts of kindness, service, and prayer. A genuine expression of love and gratitude, however small, is valuable to God. Your life can become a living testament to His grace and faithfulness.
faqs.question: Q4: How can someone who feels inadequate in expressing themselves still fulfill this verse?

faqs.answer: Psalm 106:2 introduces the theme of God's greatness and our inability to fully express it. The rest of the psalm then contrasts this with Israel's constant failures and ingratitude, highlighting God's undeserved mercy and faithfulness despite their shortcomings. This serves as a powerful reminder.
